Translation: a/ the white house
I am nice and happy.
I saw a very beautiful cow.
I am happy about Maria.
I am happy about my work.
I am happy about my work.
I know a happy man about his work.
I know a happy man about his work.
the man who came
the girl to whom you told the story
the man whom Maria saw
the woman Juan loves/ the woman who loves Juan
Comment: Adjective clauses are subjected to case marking. Without case marking, the both interpretations are possible.

Translation: The cow which the boy bought is a good cow.
I love the girl who had danced with Juan.
Comment: The head and the modifying clause are each case-marked to indicate the grammatical role of the relative clause as a whole.

Translation: Juan hit the man who saw Maria/whom Maria saw.
Juan hit the man who saw Maria/whom Maria saw.
Juan hit the man who saw Maria/whom Maria saw.
Juan hit (the so-called) Marya man.
Comment: In this sentence, Marya is the runa (man) who got hit. The word “rikushka” here has the “so called” meaning.

Translation: Jose made that house.
His father hit that child.
to the house
the man from Quito
That man from Quito worked very well.
That man from Quito worked very well.
that big black house

Morphemic: chay fiuka riku-shka Utavalu-manda shamu-shka runa
Gloss: that I see-NMLZ Otavalo-from come-NMLZ man
